intro: Calea eupatorioides, commonly known as the "flower of the night," is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that open at night and close in the morning. The plant belongs to the Asteraceae family and is known for its aromatic, tubular flowers that attract nocturnal pollinators such as moths. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its unique appearance. Calea eupatorioides is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has been used in traditional medicine for various purposes.
